Press Releases

1998

  

 


NEC Electronics VR4300, VR4310 Processors Power New HP LaserJet Printers
 

  

HP Broadens Use of VR Series RISC Processors in Printers

SANTA CLARA, Calif. (Oct. 29, 1998) -- NEC Electronics Inc. today announced that its VR4300™ and VR4310™ MIPS® RISC microprocessors have been adopted for Hewlett-Packard Company's new HP Color LaserJet 4500 and LaserJet 8100 printers.

These are the fourth and fifth HP printers to adopt the NEC VR Series™ processors. The 64-bit VR4300 and VR4310 microprocessors help the new systems redefine current printing standards for high-volume networked environments and workgroups.

Although each printer is designed to handle considerably different color and monochrome printing tasks, these members of the VR4300 processor family adapt to fulfill the needs of each: high performance, high speed and low cost. This team of CPUs is capable of processing large volumes of data and keeping pace with the speed and requirements of the printers.

"NEC's technology in these two processors embodies the essential qualities of HP's high-performance standards," said Walt Sledzieski, general manager for HP's North American Commercial Marketing Center. "Combining NEC's cutting-edge products with HP's leadership in the printing arena allows us to provide customers with versatility at a price they can afford."

The efficient VR4310 processor packs 167MHz of power for the LaserJet 8100 to provide enhanced throughput, enable systems to deliver 32 pages per minute (PPM) and manage a variety of paper-handling capabilities. The versatile new monochrome printer makes printing in high-volume, networked environments easier and offers features that previously benefited only users of personal printers or high-end digital copiers, for example, private printing and printing secure documents from the control panel, all at a lower total cost of ownership.

The VR4300 processor optimizes data throughput to deliver exceptional performance for corporate workgroups with the Color LaserJet 4500 printer. This printing solution requires high performance for processing a greater number of pixels and data bits than an equivalent speed monochrome printer would need. The Color LaserJet 4500 printer can produce high-quality color presentations, fliers, sales materials and reports easily and effectively at an affordable cost. End-users will be the beneficiaries of the high-speed data computations provided by NEC's award-winning 133MHz VR4300 CPU, with an engine speed offering up to four PPM color and 16 PPM monochrome.

"The VR4310 and VR4300 processors meet HP's demand for high-powered, cost-effective solutions," said Ray Newstead, associate vice president and general manager of Micro products for NEC Electronics Inc. "The architecture incorporated in the award-winning VR4300 family that powers HP's new printers makes it possible for NEC to provide its customers with an effective combination of low cost, speed and performance."

The powerful VR4300 family of processors incorporates an extremely broad and flexible architecture. This flexibility allows OEMs to efficiently match their product requirements and controller solutions to address a wide range of product needs with a common design and code base for maximum scalability. The VR4300 family is currently used in five HP printers: LaserJet 4000 printer (BYTE's Best of Show Award, Comdex Fall '97) , LaserJet 5000, LaserJet 8000, Color LaserJet 4500 and LaserJet 8100 printers.

About the VR4300 Processors
The VR4300 CPU is a 64-bit microprocessor with 64-bit registers, data paths and buffers to ensure high-speed data movement within the chip. The 64-bit paths are important for operations such as bit-stream decoding and matrix manipulation, core requirements in graphics processing. Graphics performance is enhanced by the double-precision floating-point operations supported by the VR4300 processor.

Offering an estimated performance of 170 MIPS at 133MHz, the VR4300 processor includes a high-performance memory management unit (MMU) and a high-throughput 32-bit external bus. A large on-chip cache (16-kilobyte instruction and 8-kilobyte data) provides high performance by reducing the need for frequent memory accesses. The power-managed VR4300 processor is ideally suited for embedded printer applications, as the 133MHz version dissipates approximately 2.2 watts and operates at 3.3 volts.

As part of its extensive VR Series 64-bit processor suite, NEC's VR4300 family of 64-bit MIPS RISC microprocessors has three members, the VR4300 (in 100- and 133MHz versions), the VR4305™ (at 80MHz) and the VR4310 (in 133- and 167MHz versions).

These processors scale a wide range of price and performance using the versatile VR4300 architecture and are widely used in office automation applications, advanced laser printers, Windows®-based terminals, point-of-sale terminals and consumer electronics devices. Target applications also include set-top boxes and digital televisions. The VR4300 processors are also supported by the Microsoft Windows® CE operating system for tethered embedded applications.

About NEC Electronics Inc.
NEC Electronics Inc., headquartered in Santa Clara, Calif., designs, manufactures and markets an extensive line of electronic products including ASICs, microprocessors and microcontrollers, graphics accelerators, digital signal processors (DSPs), memories and components including flat panel displays and lithium-ion batteries. The company operates a 709,000-square-foot manufacturing facility in Roseville, Calif. NEC Electronics is an affiliate of NEC Corporation (NIPNY), a multibillion international manufacturer of computer, communications and semiconductor products. For more information about products offered by NEC Electronics Inc., please visit the NEC U.S. Web site at www.nec.com.
